Regularly refreshing your gaming accessories is never a bad idea. This is true whether you play on PC, PS5, Xbox, or Switch. Luckily, for Cyber Monday, you can save on Razer brand keyboards, gaming mice, controllers, headsets, and more. Many of these devices are cross-platform, and all offer Razer's signature matte-black style and high build quality. There are quite a few Razer products in Amazon's Cyber Monday sale, so we've gone ahead and rounded up our favorites in the lists below. Just note that they'll be on sale for a limited time, and we don't expect them to be available after Cyber Monday.

After you've browsed the Razer accessories deals below, be sure to also check out these Cyber Monday deals on Razer's gaming chairs. We also have a list of the best PS5, Xbox, PC, and Switch 1/2 controller deals available in Amazon's event. For even more hardware deals, as well as last-minute price cuts on video games, Blu-ray, and beyond, head over to GameSpot's Cyber Monday deals hub.

Razer Gaming Headset Cyber Monday Deals

If you're looking for a headset, check out the deals on models like the Blackshark V2 Pro for PS5, which is on sale for $110 (was $200). While Razer's flagship Blackshark V3 Pro headset has succeeded it, the V2 Pro model still provides a comfortable, wireless fit thanks to noise-isolating earcups with soft memory foam cushioning, a bass-heavy profile fine-tuned for gaming, and a detachable unidirectional boom mic. The headset can run for up to 70 hours on a full charge and is compatible with PC, PS5, Switch 2, and Switch consoles.

If you don't mind wires, we'd also recommend the Blackshark V2 X headset for $35 (was $50), which works on all PCs and consoles via the 3.5mm audio jack. This headset offers platform-specific spatial audio support, and the lightweight design makes it easy and comfortable to wear all day. Other budget-friendly models on sale include the BlackShark V3 X for $75 (was $100) and the cute Razer Kraken Kitty V2 wired headset for $66 (Was $100).

It comes with a wrist rest, per-key RGB lighting, and it's on sale for $65 (was $80). item.title: High On Life 2 Trailer Encourges You To Take Drugs Made From Humans
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Humans aren't exactly on the top of the food chain in Squanch Games' High on Life 2. This first-person shooter takes place in a universe where aliens came to Earth to use humanity as ingredients for intergalactic pharmaceutical drugs. Now, a new trailer for the game facetiously markets itself to alien consumers as it encourages them to use Humanzapro, a new wonder drug made from humans.

The trailer is done in the style of pharmaceutical ads that typically run on American TV. All of the tropes of those ads are present, including the footage of happy aliens after they've taken the drug. Intriguingly, the ad warns humans that they shouldn't be taking Humanzapro because of side effects. That makes us wonder if this particular drug will be a power-up during the game.

High on Life introduced players to the Rick and Morty-esque talkative sci-fi weapons, which was fitting since the first game was produced by Rick and Morty co-creator--and Squanch Games co-founder--Justin Roiland, who also voiced a sentient alien weapon. Roiland was forced out of Squanch Games and Rick and Morty following a series of allegations.

The sequel is introducing a new feature that will let players skateboard into battle and incorporate it into their offensive moves. Alternatively, players can use the boards to perform tricks.

High on Life 2 will hit PlayStation 5, Xbox Series X|S, and PC on February 13, 2026. It's also slated to be a day-one Game Pass Ultimate release for PC and Xbox Series X|S. Outside of the game, it was reported that a High on Life animated series is in development.

item.title: Industry Mourns Tomonobu Itagaki, Creator Of Dead Or Alive And 3D Ninja Gaiden
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Industry leaders in Japan recently gathered to honor Tomonobu Itagaki, the creator of Dead or Alive and the 3D Ninja Gaiden series, who passed away in October at age 58. The memorial venue was filled with heartfelt tributes, including copies of his games, artwork, swords, and pieces of his iconic clothing. Photos shared by attendees showed just how much he meant to the gaming community.

Itagaki was a major figure in Japanese game development. He founded Team Ninja in the late 1990s and helped shape modern action and fighting games. At the memorial, Koei Tecmo executive Yosuke Hayashi shared memories of meeting him in 2001. Hayashi recalled being assigned to Itagaki's team and being told there was no work for him.

"I was assigned to your department as a game planner. You told me you had no work for me. Thatâ€™s what you told me. Two weeks after I was assigned, I really had no work, haha. At the time, I lamented my bad luck, thinking it was the worst possible encounter," he said (via a Redditor translator).

Hayashi's strongest memory was developing Ninja Gaiden for the Xbox between 2003 and 2004. He said the project felt chaotic and sometimes impossible, but Itagaki never gave up. "The two of us spent 12 hours every night checking every adjustment to the game," he said. When talking about his former mentor, Hayashi added, "You were so pure and cool," showing how much respect he still held for him.

Itagaki left Tecmo in 2008 after legal disputes, though he had been declared innocent of harassment charges in court the year before. He later reached a settlement with Koei Tecmo over unpaid bonuses for Dead or Alive 4 and went on to create Devil's Third at Valhalla Game Studios. Before leaving Tecmo, he told Hayashi, "Don't change the logo," a message Hayashi remembered for years.

Hayashi also shared the final message he received from Itagaki: "Thank you for remembering our promise. Times have changed ... selling a million copies doesn't earn you much recognition anymore. Please keep making great products from now on."

After his death, a final note appeared on Itagaki's Facebook page. "My life was a continuous battle which I kept winning. I caused a lot of trouble for others too," it read via Facebook translation. "I take pride in having fought to the end, and having followed my convictions. I have no regrets, but I am deeply sorry that I could not deliver new works to my fans. I'm sorry. So it goes."

item.title: Red Dead Redemption's New Modern Upgrade Shown Off In First Gameplay Footage
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Last month, word broke that Rockstar Games' seminal Western Red Dead Redemption is getting a modern update for PlayStation 5, Xbox Series X|S, and Switch 2. It's going to officially launch on December 2, but the upgrade is already going live in different territories. Now, the first footage of Red Dead Redemption's new update running on PS5 is already online.

GameRiot shared the following video of the opening minutes of Red Dead Redemption running 60 frames per second on PS5. Rockstar says the update provides the game with "enhanced image quality, HDR support, and resolutions up to 4K."

According to PureXbox, the Red Dead Redemption upgrade for Xbox Series X|S for in New Zealand is already going for 50% off. Whether that discount will be offered in other territories remains unclear at the moment.

Developers Double Eleven and Cast Iron Games developed the new version of Red Dead Redemption for Rockstar Games. Players who already have the PlayStation 4, Xbox One, and Switch ports will be able to get a free digital upgrade for their respective modern systems. PS4 and Switch players will also get to utilize their saved game data after the upgrade is downloaded.

Red Dead Redemption's modern upgrade will also be coming to PlayStation Plus and the GTA+ subscription service on December 2. There have been rumors that Red Dead Redemption 2 may get upgrades for PS5 Xbox Series X|S, and Switch 2. However, that remains unconfirmed for now.
